claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination broadens the repertoire of tumor antigens presented to T cells.

evidence.quote: Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3%
A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: The tumor sensitization effect by mRNA vaccination is dependent on the downstream signaling of Type I interferon.

evidence.quote: Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.

claims.claim: The combination of intratumoral mRNA vaccine and ICI therapy significantly increases immune cell infiltration into the tumor microenvironment.

evidence.quote: Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.

claims.claim: Prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination correlates with improved survival outcomes for metastatic patients treated with immune checkpoint blockade.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A
Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment

claims.caveat: Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
